div1.p: Flannagan sends a resolution passed by the Southern Medical Association about Henry Rose Carter and an essay listing Henry Rose Carter as one of the seven greatest Americans.

div1.head: Letter from Roy K. Flannagan to Laura Armistead Carter, December 5, 1925
div1.opener:
SECTION ON PUBLIC HEALTH
DR. W. G. SMILLIE, CHAIRMAN
ANDALUSIA, ALA.
DR. R. M. ADAMS, VICE-CHAIRMAN
COUNTY HEALTH OFFICER
TUPELO, MISS.
DR. ROY K. FLANNAGAN, SECRETARY
STATE OFFICE BUILDING
RICHMOND, VA.
Southern Medical Association
Southern Medical Journal
NEXT MEETING: DALLAS, TEXAS NOVEMBER 9-12, 1925
State Office Building,
Richmond, Virginia,
December 5, 1925.
Miss Laura Carter,
International Health Board,
New York City.
My dear Miss Carter:
div1.p:
Enclosed you will find a resolution unanimously passed
by the Section on Preventive Medicine of the Southern Medical Associa-
tion and the National Committee on Malaria Control at the recent
meeting of the Southern Medical Association in Dallas, Texas. My
illness since returning from Dallas accounts for the delay in transmitting
this paper to you.

Permit me to say that I, in common with every health
officer that ever came in contact with Dr. Carter, feel a deep sense of
personal loss in his passing. I have no hesitancy in saying that he
was the greatest man I ever knew. For fear that you may think this
statement too fulsome, I am sending to you a copy of an answer to a con-
test in the American Magazine in 1923 in which it asked for a 500 word
statement of opinion as to the seven greatest Americans living or dead.
The fact that it did not get the prize has not changed my opinion in
regard to the matter.
div1.closer:
With cordial regards,
Very truly yours, Roy K. Flannagan Roy K. Flannagan
